P001.rag_explanation:
--- Test: ultrasound ---
AI result summary:
- Detected plane: Fetal abdomen (confidence 1.00)

Relevant guideline summary:
Fetal Ultrasound Planes – Interpretation & Actions (Contextual)

1. Planes in your model:
   • Fetal brain
   • Fetal abdomen
   • Fetal femur
   • Fetal thorax

2. Fetal brain plane:
   • Used to assess brain structures, ventricles, midline, etc.
   • Normal AI detection of plane only confirms that the correct view is captured, not that the anatomy is normal.
   - Clinical action:
     • If plane is correctly captured and no obvious abnormality is seen, continue routine antenatal care.
     • If clinically suspected risk (e.g., prior anomaly, infections), detailed anomaly scan or fetal medicine referral may be needed.

3. Fetal abdomen plane:
   • Used for abdominal circumference, organs, and growth assessment.
   - Clinical action:
     • If plane captured and basic evaluation is normal, routine follow-up.
     • Abnormal findings (if any) must be interpreted by radiologist / fetal medicine specialist.

4. Fetal thorax plane:
   • Shows heart and lungs region.
   - Clinical action:
     • Routine follow-up if heart and lungs appear normal.
     • If structural heart disease suspected, fetal echocardiography referral.

5. Fetal femur plane:
   • Used for fetal femur length and growth assessment.
   - Clinical action:
     • If length appears consistent with gestational age, no special action.
     • If short femur or growth restriction suspected, further evaluation for IUGR or genetic conditions may be needed.

IMPORTANT:
   • Your AI model only detects the plane type (brain/abdomen/thorax/femur), not detailed anomalies.
   • Final interpretation is always by a qualified radiologist or obstetrician.
--- Test: blood_test ---
AI result summary:
- Parsed lab data: {'fasting_glucose': 71.0, 'postprandial_glucose': 91.0, 'hba1c': 5.3, 'severity': 'Normal'}
- Lab severity: Normal

Relevant guideline summary:
Diabetes – Clinical Interpretation & Actions

1. Key lab values:
   • Fasting Plasma Glucose (FPG):
     - Normal: < 100 mg/dL
     - Prediabetes: 100–125 mg/dL
     - Diabetes: ≥ 126 mg/dL (on two separate occasions)
   • Postprandial Glucose (PPG, 2 hours after meal):
     - Normal: < 140 mg/dL
     - Prediabetes: 140–199 mg/dL
     - Diabetes: ≥ 200 mg/dL
   • HbA1c:
     - Normal: < 5.7%
     - Prediabetes: 5.7–6.4%
     - Diabetes: ≥ 6.5%

2. Mild abnormality (Prediabetes):
   - Typical pattern: borderline high fasting or PP or HbA1c in 5.7–6.4 range.
   - Clinical action:
     • Lifestyle advice (diet, exercise, weight control).
     • Repeat test in 3–6 months.
     • Consider early endocrinology referral if strong family history, obesity, or other risk factors.

3. Severe abnormality (Diabetes range):
   - Any of:
     • FPG ≥ 126 mg/dL
     • PP ≥ 200 mg/dL
     • HbA1c ≥ 6.5%
   - Clinical action:
     • Confirm with repeat test (if not already confirmed).
     • Start diabetes management plan as per local protocol.
     • Refer to diabetologist / general physician.
     • Educate patient about diet, foot care, eye screening, and regular follow-up.

4. When values are fully normal:
   - Clinical action:
     • Reassure patient.
     • Advise routine annual checkup if risk factors present.
     • If patient is already diabetic on treatment but results are normal, continue same medication and follow-up schedule unless symptoms suggest otherwise.

Overall AI severity for this patient: Normal
NOTE: This is clinical decision support, final decision is by the doctor.

--- Test: urine_test ---
AI result summary:
- Parsed lab data: {'pH': '6.7', 'specific_gravity': '1.01', 'protein': 'Negative', 'sugar': 'Negative', 'ketones': None, 'severity': 'Normal'}
- Lab severity: Normal

Relevant guideline summary:
Urine Report – Interpretation & Actions

1. Key parameters commonly reported:
   • pH
   • Specific Gravity
   • Protein
   • Sugar
   • Ketones
   • Microscopy (RBCs, WBCs, epithelial cells, casts, crystals)

2. Normal urine:
   • Protein: Negative
   • Sugar: Negative
   • Ketones: Negative
   • pH: Usually ~5.5–7.0
   • Specific Gravity: ~1.005–1.030 (depends on hydration)

3. Mild abnormality:
   • Trace or 1+ protein or sugar.
   • Few WBCs/RBCs.
   • Slightly altered pH or specific gravity.
   - Clinical action:
     • Correlate with symptoms (burning micturition, frequency).
     • Encourage hydration.
     • Consider repeat test or urine culture if UTI is suspected.
     • Non-urgent follow-up.

4. Severe abnormality:
   • Protein ≥ 2+ or 3+.
   • Sugar ≥ 2+.
   • Presence of significant ketones.
   • Heavy pyuria or hematuria.
   - Clinical action:
     • Evaluate for renal disease, uncontrolled diabetes, or severe infection.
     • Refer to physician / nephrologist.
     • Additional tests (renal function tests, ultrasound, culture) as appropriate.

5. When report is fully normal:
   • Clinical action:
     • Reassure patient.
     • No specific treatment needed.
     • If symptoms persist despite normal report, consider non-urinary causes.

Overall AI severity for this patient: Normal
NOTE: This is clinical decision support, final decision is by the doctor.

P004.rag_explanation:
--- Test: thyroid_test ---
AI result summary:
- Parsed lab data: {'T3': 0.63, 'T4': 4.39, 'TSH': 7.18, 'severity': 'Mild'}
- Lab severity: Mild

Relevant guideline summary:
Thyroid Function – Interpretation & Actions

1. Key parameters:
   • TSH (Thyroid Stimulating Hormone)
   • T3 (Triiodothyronine)
   • T4 (Thyroxine)

2. Typical reference ranges (may vary by lab):
   • TSH:
     - Normal: ~0.4–4.5 mIU/L
     - Mild abnormal:
       • 0.1–0.39 (possible mild hyperthyroidism)
       • 4.5–10 (possible mild hypothyroidism)
     - Severe abnormal:
       • < 0.1 (marked hyperthyroidism)
       • > 10 (marked hypothyroidism)

3. Mild thyroid abnormality:
   - Lab pattern:
     • Slightly high or low TSH with near-normal T3/T4.
   - Clinical action:
     • Correlate with symptoms (fatigue, weight change, palpitations, etc.).
     • Repeat test in 6–8 weeks to confirm trend.
     • Consider starting low-dose treatment if persistent and symptomatic.
     • Non-urgent endocrinology referral.

4. Severe thyroid abnormality:
   - Lab pattern:
     • TSH > 10 or < 0.1, often with abnormal T3/T4.
   - Clinical action:
     • Endocrinology referral recommended.
     • Start treatment as per protocol.
     • Monitor for cardiac and metabolic complications.
     • Urgent review if patient is pregnant or has cardiac disease.

5. Normal thyroid profile:
   - Clinical action:
     • Reassure patient.
     • No specific thyroid treatment required.
     • If symptoms persist, consider non-thyroidal causes (anemia, depression, etc.).

Overall AI severity for this patient: Mild
NOTE: This is clinical decision support, final decision is by the doctor.

P005.rag_explanation:
--- Test: bp_test ---
AI result summary:
- Parsed lab data: {'systolic': None, 'diastolic': None, 'severity': 'Normal'}
- Lab severity: Normal

Relevant guideline summary:
Blood Pressure – Interpretation & Actions (Adults)

1. Typical categories (office readings):
   • Normal:
     - Systolic < 120 mmHg AND Diastolic < 80 mmHg
   • Prehypertension / Elevated:
     - Systolic 120–139 OR Diastolic 80–89 mmHg
   • Hypertension:
     - Systolic ≥ 140 OR Diastolic ≥ 90 mmHg

2. Mild elevation:
   • 120–139 / 80–89.
   - Clinical action:
     • Lifestyle modification (salt restriction, exercise, weight control).
     • Repeat measurements on different days.
     • No emergency if asymptomatic.

3. Severe elevation:
   • ≥ 140/90 on multiple readings.
   - Clinical action:
     • Evaluate for chronic hypertension.
     • Start or adjust antihypertensive medication as per guidelines.
     • Screen for end organ damage (eyes, kidneys, heart).

4. Hypertensive emergency (for awareness):
   • Very high BP with organ damage (e.g., chest pain, breathlessness, neurological deficit).
   - Clinical action:
     • Immediate referral to emergency / ICU.
     • IV medications in hospital setting (not managed by this AI system).

5. Normal BP report:
   • Clinical action:
     • Reassure patient.
     • Continue current medication if already on treatment and BP is controlled.
     • Routine follow-up as per physician advice.

Overall AI severity for this patient: Normal
NOTE: This is clinical decision support, final decision is by the doctor.

P006.rag_explanation:
--- Test: ct_scan ---
AI result summary:
- CT classification: meningioma (confidence 0.99)

Relevant guideline summary:
CT Brain – Tumor Type Overview & Actions

1. Common brain lesions in your model:
   • Glioma
   • Meningioma
   • Pituitary lesion
   • No tumor (notumor)

2. Glioma:
   • Often infiltrative brain tumor; may be low or high grade.
   • Symptoms: seizures, headache, neurological deficits.
   • CT/ MRI usually required for further characterization.
   - Clinical action:
     • Refer to neurosurgeon / neuro-oncologist.
     • MRI brain with contrast usually recommended.
     • Further management based on neurosurgical opinion and histopathology.

3. Meningioma:
   • Typically extra-axial, often benign but may cause mass effect.
   • Symptoms: depends on location; headache, focal deficits, seizures.
   - Clinical action:
     • Neurosurgical or neuro-oncology referral.
     • MRI for better definition.
     • Management may be observation or surgery based on size and symptoms.

4. Pituitary tumor:
   • Located in sellar region.
   • May cause hormonal imbalance or visual symptoms.
   - Clinical action:
     • Endocrinology and neurosurgery referral.
     • MRI sella with contrast.
     • Hormonal workup (prolactin, cortisol, etc.) as per protocol.

5. No tumor (notumor class):
   • AI model did not detect a mass lesion.
   - Clinical action:
     • Correlate with symptoms; CT may still show non-tumor pathology (e.g., bleed, infarct) which AI is not classifying.
     • If CT is otherwise normal and symptoms are mild, outpatient follow-up is reasonable.
     • Urgent referral if red-flag symptoms present (sudden severe headache, neurological deficit, seizures).

IMPORTANT:
   • AI output is not a final diagnosis.
   • All CT findings must be reviewed and confirmed by a radiologist.

Overall AI severity for this patient: Severe
NOTE: This is clinical decision support, final decision is by the doctor.
